title: Decomposing ℝⁿ into Sets with Distinct Distances
description: Can ℝⁿ be decomposed into countably many sets where all pairwise distances within each set are distinct? YES assuming the Continuum Hypothesis (Erdős-Kakutani 1943 for n=1, Davies 1972 for n=2, Kunen 1987 for all n). CH is necessary.

meta.author: Erdős-Kakutani (1943), Davies (1972), Kunen (1987)
originalContributions: Lean formalization of distinct distances property
Axiomatization of Erdős-Kakutani, Davies, and Kunen theorems

overview.historicalContext: This problem connects geometry to set theory in a surprising way. Erdős and Kakutani (1943) showed that for n=1, the decomposition exists if and only if the Continuum Hypothesis holds. Davies (1972) proved the n=2 case under CH, and Kunen (1987) proved it for all dimensions. Erdős and Hajnal showed that CH is necessary - without it, even finite partitions fail.
overview.problemStatement: Can ℝⁿ be decomposed into countably many sets, such that within each set all pairwise distances are distinct?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines the distinct distances property, countable decomposition, and the Continuum Hypothesis. Key results are axiomatized: Erdős-Kakutani equivalence (CH ↔ ℝ = countable union of ℚ-linearly independent sets), Davies' theorem for n=2, Kunen's theorem for all n, and the Erdős-Hajnal necessity result.
keyInsights: The answer is YES assuming the Continuum Hypothesis
Erdős-Kakutani: CH is EQUIVALENT to ℝ being a countable union of ℚ-linearly independent sets
ℚ-linear independence implies distinct pairwise distances
CH is NECESSARY: without it, even finite decomposition fails (Erdős-Hajnal)
Beautiful connection between set theory, linear algebra, and geometry

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #1127 is SOLVED: ℝⁿ can be decomposed into countably many sets with distinct pairwise distances, assuming the Continuum Hypothesis. This was proved progressively: Erdős-Kakutani for n=1, Davies for n=2, Kunen for all n. The CH is necessary (Erdős-Hajnal).
conclusion.implications: This result demonstrates a deep connection between the Continuum Hypothesis (a fundamental question in set theory) and geometric distance problems. It shows how questions about infinite sets can depend on set-theoretic axioms.
openQuestions: What happens in models of ZFC where CH fails?
Are there weaker set-theoretic hypotheses that suffice?
What is the relationship to other distance problems (unit distance, distinct distances)?
